title: A Royal Friend and a Money Man
summary: This article talks about emails that show Prince Andrew, a member of the British royal family, had a close friend named David Rowland who helped him with money. Prince Andrew called Rowland his 'trusted money man' in messages to Jeffrey Epstein, a businessman who got into trouble. The emails suggest Prince Andrew tried to get Epstein to invest in Rowland's business projects. Rowland was a rich donor to a political party, but some people in the UK called him a 'shady financier,' which means they thought he might not be honest. Epstein did not want to work with Rowland after hearing this. The emails also mention that Rowland might have lent money to Prince Andrew's ex-wife, Sarah Ferguson, for things like a first-class flight to Nepal. Regulators have taken away the banking license from Rowland's bank, Banque Havilland, because of problems. The article says there are many questions about Prince Andrew's money and his friendship with Rowland, but not all claims are proven.

background_read: This article is about Prince Andrew, who is part of the British royal family and used to be a trade envoy for the UK. It discusses emails that show his relationship with David Rowland, a businessman who helped with money matters. The emails were released as part of a bigger investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, who was involved in financial crimes. The story raises questions about how public figures manage their finances and who they trust with their money.
